TITLE:

   Maps in  high 50s;
   Gave 5 mg bolus of dilt, maxed out dilt gtt to 20 mg/hr...hypotensive
   with maps in 50s, increased neo to 1.2...finally broke...started
   standing po dilt 60 mg TID
   A-line placed

   NECK: Supple with JVP of difficult to estimate [**1-28**] habitus.
   CARDIAC: NSR, RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g.
   LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Course breath

                                   proBNP

   Other labs: CK / CKMB / Troponin-T:64//0.14, Ca++:8.3 mg/dL, Mg++:1.8
   mg/dL, PO4:3.5 mg/dL
   Lipid Panel: Pending; AST/ALT; Pending
   Sputum Gram Stain: oropharyngeal flora
   Blood Cx, Urine Cx, Sputum Cx: all pending
   CXR:
   The hila are prominent, with additional confluent perihilar opacities,
   as well as patchy opacity
   at the left base and peripherally in the left midlung. Findings may
   represent a combination of perihilar
   edema and adenopathy/chronic interstitial changes from patient's known
   sarcoid, but superimposed pneumonia cannot be excluded.
   CXR this AM pending
   Assessment and Plan
   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents  with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient also with AFib with RVR causing hypotension. Also with mild
   troponin increase of 0.12 (peaked at 0.27 in OSH), ischemic changes on
   EKG (TWI) : Sent for cath and found 2 vessel disease, s/p BMS to LAD.
   .
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: found to have 2 vessel disease on cardiac cath.
   s/p BMS to the mid LAD. ? whether this was a primary coronary event or
   demand [**1-28**] RVR as pt. had acute heart failure yesterday and still has
   not significantly increased her troponin, would have expected large
   bump by now if infarct large enough to cause LV failure. EKG does
   appear to be c/w s/p anterior infarct.
   -Integrillin gtt until 18 hours post cath (stop at 1100)
   -Plavix 75 mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Start Aspirin desensitisation protocal
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   - Start metroprolol low dose later today.
   -Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension and dye in cath
   - TTE in am to check for WMA
   .
   # PUMP: Noted to have EF of 60-70% on [**5-27**]. Current BNP elevated to
   [**Numeric Identifier 8933**].  Fluid overload possibly secondary afib with RVR; this is likely
   the etiology behind her flash pulmonary edema.
   -Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and on Phenylephrine
   -Once stable, will consider diuresing
   -FU TTE today
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with h/o afib with RVR, presents to unit in afib with
   RVR and hemodynamically unstable.
   -Dilt gtt started, bolus of 20 mg with infusion of [**5-15**] mg/hr as
   tolerated maintain HR < 110;
   - Since patient has a DDD pacemaker, will give as much nodal agents as
   needed for RVR, as patient will be paced out of bradycardia.
   - Neo gtt to maintain MAP > 60
   - Start low dose metroprolol later today after ASA desensitization.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR elevated to 2.3; continue home dose of coumadin as patient is at
   goal, but will hold heparin gtt.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF
   -intubated on AC; Will attempt PS today and ultimately wean from vent
   when HD stable; RISBI overnight was 29
   - Check ABG's in AM
   - Start Lasix 20 mg IV, FU I/Os adjust as needed.
   - CXR in AM
   -  Attempt extubation today.
   # Respiratory Acidosis with Metabolic Compensation: Patient h/o COPD on
   home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis. Acid/Base disturbance likely
   secondary to COPD, as patient may be a CO2 retainer.
   -Continue to monitor with ABG's
   -Adjust major acid/base disturbances with ventilation manipulation
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Patient had wbc in OSH of 8.4 on [**7-15**], currently  24.2.
   Patient spiked to 101.1, and CXR shows new middle lobe infilitrate.
   Also, C.diff cannot be ruled out as pt. w/ h/o diarrhea and acutely
   high WBC.
   - BCX, UCx and sputum culture, and C. diff toxin pending
   -Will start empiric treatment of VAP since new infiltrate shown on CXR;
   will start 7 day course of vanc/cefepime: will need ID approval
   -Since white count is markedly elevated and patient has h/o diarrhea,
   cannot exclude C. diff. Will start empiric treatment with flaygl
   pending c. diff toxin results.
   .
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Continue Prednisone 5 mg qAM and 2.5 mg qPM
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now
   -Start humulog ISS for more predictable control
   -FSBS qachs
   .
   # Dyslipidemia: Do not have recent lipid panel.
   -Will hold zetia
   -Will check lipid panel this AM
   -Start simvistatin 80 mg daily
   # HTN: patient currently hypotensive
   -Currently normotensive.
   # Hypothyroidism:
   -Continue Synthroid at 25 mcg daily
   # Depression:
   -Continue Paroxetine 10 mg daily
   # GERD:
   -Start H2 blocker (Famotidine) as PPI interacts with Plavix
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now; if fails weaning today, consider tube feeds;
   if successful extubation, attempt po diet
   Glycemic Control:  ISS
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2182-7-16**] 07:06 PM left femoral
   20 Gauge - [**2182-7-17**] 12:50 AM
   Consider PICC line.
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  boots, therapeutic INR
   Stress ulcer:  Famotidine 20 mg daily
   VAP:  HOB 30 degrees
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:  Husband [**Name (NI) 135**] [**Name (NI) 2415**]: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8934**] (health
   care proxy)
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:  CCU for now
   ------ Protected Section ------
   Cardiology Teaching Physician Note
   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
   agree with the above note and plans.
   I would add the following remarks:
   History
   Rapid af leading to troponin elevation in setting of a tight distal lad
   lesion that was stented.  She has severe mulitiorgan sarcoidosis with
   muiltiple potential cardiac manifestation including heart block (at one
   time) requiring ddd pacer, atrial arrhythmias for which she was on
   sotalol for a while; even her cad could possibly be from sarcoid but
   obviously most likely from her usual risk factors of htn,
   hyperlipidemia, obesity, age, and diabetes.  I suspect that her atrial
   arrhythmias will be difficult to manage so we should get an eps
   consult.
   Physical Examination
   echo shows apical hk of the lv and apical akinesis of the rv with
   severe pulm htn (interestingly the rhc demonstrated only mild elevation
   of pulm vasc resistance which means that most of the blame for the pulm
   htn rests on diastolic dysfunction of the left ventricle)
   Medical Decision Making
   Since it is of paramount importance to maintain sinus rhythm (or at
   very least a well-controlled ventricular rate in af), and since she has
   lung disease possibly precluding the drug of choice (amiodarone), we
   will get an eps consult.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) **]  on:[**2182-7-17**]
   11:14 ------

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and sarcoidosis. She presented to the hospital with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T = 37.1°C (98.8°F), HR = 69 bpm, BP = 87/36 mmHg, RR = 17 breaths per minute, SpO2 = 96%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's mean arterial pressure (MAP) is 60 mmHg, which is low. The patient is receiving a dopamine infusion to maintain MAP > 60 mmHg.
* Respiratory support: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The ventilator settings include a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.
* Laboratory results: The patient's troponin level is mildly elevated at 0.12 ng/mL, and her brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level is elevated at 8933 pg/mL.
* Imaging studies: A chest X-ray (CXR) shows bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and prominent hila, which may represent a combination of perihilar edema and adenopathy/chronic interstitial changes from the patient's known sarcoidosis.

The patient's medical complications and potential medical complications include:

* Acute heart failure and flash pulmonary edema
* Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR)
* Hypotension
* Respiratory failure
* Leukocytosis
* Sarcoidosis
* Diabetes type 2
* Dyslipidemia
* Hypothyroidism
* Depression
* GERD

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Cardioversion to sinus rhythm
* Management of atrial fibrillation with amiodarone or sotalol
* Management of hypertension with medications and lifestyle modifications
* Management of hyperlipidemia with statins
* Management of diabetes with insulin and lifestyle modifications
* Management of sarcoidosis with corticosteroids and other medications
* Management of respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy
* Management of leukocytosis with antibiotics and other medications
* Management of depression with antidepressants and other medications
* Management of GERD with proton pump inhibitors and other medications.

The patient's prognosis is guarded due to her multiple medical complications and potential medical complications. Close monitoring and management of her condition are essential to prevent further complications and improve her outcome.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old female with a complex medical history, including diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and sarcoidosis. She presented to the ICU with acute heart failure, flash pulmonary edema, and NSTEMI/STEMI with 2-vessel disease on cardiac catheterization.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic instability: The patient is hypotensive with a blood pressure of 87/36 mmHg and a heart rate of 69 bpm.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated with a respiratory rate of 17 inspirations per minute and a partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) of 33 mmHg.
* Renal failure: The patient has a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 29.5 mL/min.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has an elevated potassium level of 5.2 mEq/L and a low magnesium level of 1.1 mg/dL.
* Infection: The patient has leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 24.2 K/uL and is at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Other medical conditions: The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and her acid-base status is likely secondary to COPD.

The patient's medications include:

* Anticoagulants: Plavix 75 mg daily and heparin infusion
* Antiplatelet agents: Integrilin infusion
* Vasodilators: Diltiazem infusion
* Beta blockers: Metoprolol 25 mg daily
* Diuretics: Hold for now due to hypotension
* Antibiotics: Empiric treatment for VAP with vancomycin and cefepime
* Anti-inflammatory agents: Prednisone 5 mg daily
* Antihypertensive agents: Hold for now due to hypotension
* Antihyperlipidemic agents: Simvastatin 80 mg daily
* Thyroid replacement therapy: Synthroid 25 mcg daily
* Antidepressants: Paroxetine 10 mg daily
* Proton pump inhibitors: Hold due to interaction with Plavix

The patient's lab results include:

* Troponin-T: 0.14 ng/mL
* Creatine kinase (CK): 64 U/L
* Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): 192 U/L
* Alanine transaminase (ALT): 27 U/L
* Aspartate transaminase (AST): 102 U/L
* Calcium: 8.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.5 mg/dL
* Potassium: 5.2 mEq/L
* Sodium: 143 mEq/L
* Chloride: 102 mEq/L

The patient's radiology results include:

* Chest X-ray: Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, likely secondary to flash pulmonary edema and acute heart failure.

Based on the patient's condition and lab results, the potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of AFib with RVR and is currently on antiarrhythmic medications.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and is at risk for respiratory failure due to her underlying COPD and acute heart failure.
* Renal failure: The patient has a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL and an eGFR of 29.5 mL/min, which may indicate renal failure.
* Infection: The patient has leukocytosis and is at risk for VAP and other infections.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has an elevated potassium level and low magnesium level, which may indicate electrolyte imbalance.
* Acute coronary syndrome: The patient has a history of NSTEMI/STEMI and is currently on antiplatelet and anticoagulant medications.

Based on the patient's condition and lab results, the plan of care includes:

* Monitoring of vital signs and lab results
* Management of cardiac arrhythmias with antiarrhythmic medications
* Management of respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy
* Management of renal failure with diuretics and hemodialysis
* Management of infection with antibiotics and other antimicrobial agents
* Management of electrolyte imbalance with electrolyte replacement therapy
* Management of acute coronary syndrome with antiplatelet and anticoagulant medications.

   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents  with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient also with AFib with RVR causing hypotension. Also with mild
   troponin increase of 0.12 (peaked at 0.27 in OSH), ischemic changes on
   EKG (TWI) : Sent for cath and found 2 vessel disease, s/p BMS to LAD.

   s/p BMS to the mid LAD. ? whether this was a primary coronary event or
   demand [**1-28**] RVR as pt. had acute heart failure yesterday and still has
   not significantly increased her troponin, would have expected large
   bump by now if infarct large enough to cause LV failure. EKG does
   appear to be c/w s/p anterior infarct.
   -Integrillin gtt until 18 hours post cath (stop at 1100)
   -Plavix 75 mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Start Aspirin desensitisation protocal
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   - Start metroprolol low dose later today.
   -Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension and dye in cath
   - TTE in am to check for WMA
   .
   # PUMP: Noted to have EF of 60-70% on [**5-27**]. Current BNP elevated to
   [**Numeric Identifier 8933**].  Fluid overload possibly secondary afib with RVR; this is likely
   the etiology behind her flash pulmonary edema.
   -Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and on Phenylephrine
   -Once stable, will consider diuresing
   -FU TTE today
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with h/o afib with RVR, presents to unit in afib with
   RVR and hemodynamically unstable.
   -Dilt gtt started, bolus of 20 mg with infusion of [**5-15**] mg/hr as
   tolerated maintain HR < 110;
   - Since patient has a DDD pacemaker, will give as much nodal agents as
   needed for RVR, as patient will be paced out of bradycardia.
   - Neo gtt to maintain MAP > 60
   - Start low dose metroprolol later today after ASA desensitization.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR elevated to 2.3; continue home dose of coumadin as patient is at
   goal, but will hold heparin gtt.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF
   -intubated on AC; Will attempt PS today and ultimately wean from vent
   when HD stable; RISBI overnight was 29
   - Check ABG's in AM
   - Start Lasix 20 mg IV, FU I/Os adjust as needed.
   - CXR in AM
   -  Attempt extubation today.
   # Respiratory Acidosis with Metabolic Compensation: Patient h/o COPD on
   home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis. Acid/Base disturbance likely
   secondary to COPD, as patient may be a CO2 retainer.
   -Continue to monitor with ABG's
   -Adjust major acid/base disturbances with ventilation manipulation
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Patient had wbc in OSH of 8.4 on [**7-15**], currently  24.2.
   Patient spiked to 101.1, and CXR shows new middle lobe infilitrate.
   Also, C.diff cannot be ruled out as pt. w/ h/o diarrhea and acutely
   high WBC.
   - BCX, UCx and sputum culture, and C. diff toxin pending
   -Will start empiric treatment of VAP since new infiltrate shown on CXR;
   will start 7 day course of vanc/cefepime: will need ID approval
   -Since white count is markedly elevated and patient has h/o diarrhea,
   cannot exclude C. diff. Will start empiric treatment with flaygl
   pending c. diff toxin results.
   .
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Continue Prednisone 5 mg qAM and 2.5 mg qPM
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now
   -Start humulog ISS for more predictable control
   -FSBS qachs
   .
   # Dyslipidemia: Do not have recent lipid panel.
   -Will hold zetia
   -Will check lipid panel this AM
   -Start simvistatin 80 mg daily
   # HTN: patient currently hypotensive
   -Currently normotensive.
   # Hypothyroidism:
   -Continue Synthroid at 25 mcg daily
   # Depression:
   -Continue Paroxetine 10 mg daily
   # GERD:

   Nutrition: NPO for now; if fails weaning today, consider tube feeds;
   if successful extubation, attempt po diet

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), sarcoidosis, and a pacemaker. She was admitted to the ICU with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.

The patient's condition is complex, and several potential medical complications can arise. Some of these complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to flash pulmonary edema. There is a risk of respiratory failure if the patient's condition does not improve or if there are complications with the ventilation.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of AFib with RVR, which can lead to hypotension and decreased cardiac output. There is a risk of cardiac arrest if the patient's condition does not improve.
3. Infection: The patient has a high white blood cell count and is at risk of developing an infection, particularly pneumonia. The presence of a middle lobe infiltrate on the chest X-ray suggests that the patient may have pneumonia.
4. Sepsis: The patient's high white blood cell count and the presence of a middle lobe infiltrate on the chest X-ray suggest that the patient may have sepsis.
5. C. difficile infection: The patient has a history of diarrhea and a high white blood cell count, which increases the risk of C. difficile infection.
6. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk of developing VAP due to the presence of a central line and the use of mechanical ventilation.
7. Fluid overload: The patient has fluid overload, which can lead to respiratory and cardiac complications.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can increase the risk of bleeding complications.
9. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, which can increase the risk of cardiac complications.
10. Depression: The patient has depression, which can increase the risk of cardiac complications.

To manage these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored and treated with antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and other medications as needed. The patient's family should be informed of the potential complications and the need for close monitoring.

   appear to be c/w s/p anterior infarct.
   -Integrillin gtt until 18 hours post cath (stop at 1100)
   -Plavix 75 mg [**Hospital1 7**]; NO ASA b/c of allergy
   -Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   -Low dose metoprolol as patient tolerates
   -Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension and dye in cath
   - TTE in am to check for WMA
   .
   # PUMP: Noted to have EF of 60-70% on [**5-27**]. Current BNP elevated to
   [**Numeric Identifier 8933**] -> HF possibly secondary to sarcoidosis vs. CAD;  Fluid overload
   possibly secondary to acute heart failure; this is likely the etiology
   behind her flash pulmonary edema, likely that AF acutely led to
   increased rate, decreased filling time and loss of atrial kick.
   -Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and on Phenylephrine
   -Once stable, will consider diuresing
   -Repeat TTE tomorrow
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with h/o afib with RVR, presents to unit in afib with
   RVR and hemodynamically unstable.
   -Dilt gtt started, bolus of 20 mg with infusion of [**5-15**] mg/hr as
   tolerated maintain HR < 110;
   - Since patient has a DDD pacemaker, will give as much nodal agents as
   needed for RVR, as patient will be paced out of bradycardia.
   - Neo gtt to maintain MAP > 60
   - Hold Sotolol for now
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR elevated to 2.3; continue home dose of coumadin as patient is at
   goal, but will hold heparin gtt.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF
   -intubated on AC; Will attempt PS today and ultimately wean from vent
   when HD stable; RISBI overnight was 29
   -Check ABG's in AM
   - Diurese when BP allows for better resolution of pulmonary edema
   - CXR in AM
   # Respiratory Acidosis with Metabolic Compensation: Patient h/o COPD on
   home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis. Acid/Base disturbance likely
   secondary to COPD, as patient may be a CO2 retainer.
   -Continue to monitor with ABG's
   -Adjust major acid/base disturbances with ventilation manipulation
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Patient had wbc in OSH of 8.4 on [**7-15**], currently  24.2.
   Patient spiked to 101.1, and CXR shows new middle lobe infilitrate.
   Also, C.diff cannot be ruled out as pt. w/ h/o diarrhea and acutely
   high WBC.
   - BCX, UCx and sputum culture, and C. diff toxin pending
   -Will start empiric treatment of VAP since new infiltrate shown on CXR;
   will start 7 day course of vanc/cefepime: will need ID approval
   -Since white count is markedly elevated and patient has h/o diarrhea,
   cannot exclude C. diff. Will start empiric treatment with flaygl
   pending c. diff toxin results.
   .
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Continue Prednisone 5 mg qAM and 2.5 mg qPM
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now
   -Start humulog ISS for more predictable control
   -FSBS qachs

   # Dyslipidemia: Do not have recent lipid panel.

   -Start simvistatin 80 mg daily
   # HTN: patient currently hypotensive
   -Will hold BP medication for now

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old female with a complex medical history, including diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and sarcoidosis. She presents to the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 37.1°C (98.8°F), HR 69 bpm, BP 87/36 mmHg, RR 17 breaths per minute, SpO2 96%
* Respiratory support: Intubated and mechanically ventilated with a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%
* Cardiac rhythm: Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 69 bpm
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 60 mmHg, central venous pressure (CVP) of difficult to estimate, and pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) of 32 mmHg
* Laboratory results:
	+ Troponin: 0.12 ng/mL (peaked at 0.27 ng/mL)
	+ Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
	+ Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 30 mg/dL
	+ Electrolytes: Na 143 mEq/L, K 3.7 mEq/L, Cl 102 mEq/L
	+ White blood cell count (WBC): 24.2 K/uL
	+ Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.7 g/dL
	+ Platelet count (Plt): 288 K/uL

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and there is concern about the development of respiratory acidosis and hypercapnia.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and there is concern about the development of cardiac arrhythmias and heart failure.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a high white blood cell count and a possible infection, which may lead to the development of sepsis.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient has a high creatinine level and a possible acute kidney injury.
5. Hypercalcemia: The patient has a history of hypercalcemia and may be at risk for recurrent episodes.
6. C. difficile colitis: The patient has a high white blood cell count and a possible C. difficile infection.

The patient's medications include:

* Diltiazem: 5 mg/hour infusion
* Eptifibatide: 2 mcg/kg/min infusion
* Fentanyl: 40 mcg/hour infusion
* Midazolam: 2 mg/hour infusion
* Integrilin: 2 mcg/kg/min infusion
* Plavix: 75 mg daily
* Simvastatin: 80 mg daily
* Metoprolol: low dose
* Heparin: hold due to elevated INR
* Prednisone: 5 mg qAM and 2.5 mg qPM
* Fosamax: 70 mg weekly
* Humalog ISS: to be started
* Synthroid: 25 mcg daily
* Paroxetine: 10 mg daily
* Famotidine: 20 mg daily

The patient's care plan includes:

* Continue diltiazem infusion
* Continue eptifibatide infusion
* Continue fentanyl infusion
* Continue midazolam infusion
* Continue integrilin infusion
* Start humalog ISS
* Continue prednisone
* Continue fosamax
* Continue synthroid
* Continue paroxetine
* Start famotidine
* Monitor for signs of respiratory failure, cardiac complications, sepsis, acute kidney injury, hypercalcemia, and C. difficile colitis
* Consider diuresis once the patient is hemodynamically stable
* Consider tube feeds if the patient fails weaning from the ventilator
* Consider starting PO diet if the patient is successfully extubated

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and sarcoidosis, who presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She had a previous pacemaker implantation and was found to have 2-vessel disease on cardiac catheterization, which was treated with a bare-metal stent (BMS) in the mid-left anterior descending (LAD) artery.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 37.1°C, HR 69 bpm, BP 87/36 mmHg, RR 17 inspirations per minute, SpO2 96%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is on a vasopressor (Neo) to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 339 mL of intravenous fluids and has lost 1,340 mL of fluid through diuresis.
* Respiratory support: The patient is intubated and on a ventilator in pressure support mode (PSV) with a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.
* Laboratory results:
	+ Complete Blood Count (CBC): WBC 24.2 x 10^9/L, Hct 35.1%, Plt 288 x 10^9/L
	+ Electrolytes: Na 143 mmol/L, K 3.7 mmol/L, Cl 102 mmol/L
	+ Troponin: 0.12 ng/mL
	+ Creatine kinase (CK) and CK-MB: 64 IU/L
	+ B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP): 8,933 pg/mL
* Imaging studies:
	+ Chest X-ray (CXR): New middle lobe infiltrate
	+ Electrocardiogram (ECG): Ischemic changes consistent with a previous anterior myocardial infarction

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on a ventilator, and there is a risk of respiratory failure due to her underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and there is a risk of cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, or cardiac failure.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a high white blood cell count and is at risk of developing sepsis, particularly given her history of diarrhea and the presence of a new middle lobe infiltrate on CXR.
4. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient has diabetes and is at risk of developing diabetic ketoacidosis, particularly given her high glucose levels and the presence of ketones.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism and may require thyroid hormone replacement therapy.
6. Depression: The patient has depression and may require antidepressant therapy.
7. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): The patient has GERD and may require proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy.
8. Mild transaminitis: The patient has mild transaminitis and may require further evaluation and treatment.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Vasopressor therapy to maintain a MAP above 60 mmHg.
2. Diuresis to manage fluid overload.
3. Intubation and mechanical ventilation to manage respiratory failure.
4. Antibiotics to treat potential sepsis.
5. Antiplatelet therapy to prevent cardiac complications.
6. Antiarrhythmic therapy to manage atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.
7. Thyroid hormone replacement therapy to manage hypothyroidism.
8. Antidepressant therapy to manage depression.
9. Proton pump inhibitor therapy to manage GERD.
10. Further evaluation and treatment for mild transaminitis.

Based on the progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* Patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and sarcoidosis, who presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
* She has been intubated and is on mechanical ventilation with a DDD pacemaker.
* She has had multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR) and hypotension since admission.
* She has been diagnosed with 2-vessel disease and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stenting to the mid-left anterior descending (LAD) artery.
* She has a high risk of cardiac arrhythmias and requires close monitoring and rate control.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Cardiac Arrhythmias:** The patient's history of AFib with RVR and her current DDD pacemaker increase her risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, and cardiac arrest.
2. **Pulmonary Hypertension:** The patient's severe pulmonary artery systolic hypertension increases her risk of right heart failure and pulmonary edema.
3. **Acute Renal Failure:** The patient's recent increase in creatinine levels (1.5 mg/dL) suggests prerenal azotemia, which may be related to hypotension, dye exposure during catheterization, or septic shock.
4. **Infection:** The patient's positive blood cultures for GPC (Gram-positive coccus) and her fever (102.2°F) suggest a potential bacterial infection, which may require further antibiotic treatment.
5. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient's respiratory failure may be exacerbated by her chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and her recent flash pulmonary edema.
6. **Gastrointestinal Bleeding:** The patient's history of bleeding from the oropharyngeal flora in her sputum and her recent use of anticoagulants increase her risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. **Sepsis:** The patient's fever, tachycardia, and leukocytosis suggest a potential septic response, which may require early recognition and treatment.
8. **Adrenal Insufficiency:** The patient's recent use of steroids and her history of sarcoidosis increase her risk of adrenal insufficiency, which may require close monitoring and treatment.

**Plan:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and blood pressure to prevent cardiac arrhythmias and hypotension.
2. Continue to optimize her pulmonary hypertension with diuretics and vasodilators.
3. Monitor her renal function closely and adjust her fluid management and diuretic therapy as necessary.
4. Continue to treat her infection with antibiotics and consider additional therapy for sepsis.
5. Monitor her respiratory function closely and adjust her ventilation settings as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor her gastrointestinal function and bleeding risk, and consider prophylactic treatment with antacids or H2 blockers.
7. Monitor her adrenal function closely and adjust her steroid therapy as necessary.
8. Consider consulting with an infectious disease specialist to optimize her antibiotic therapy and manage her sepsis.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, heart disease, and sarcoidosis, who presented to the hospital with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient has been experiencing episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (Afib with RVR) and hypotension since admission.

Recent events include:

* The patient had agitation and hypertension while being switched to pressure support ventilation, and was switched back to assist control.
* She was given Lasix 20mg IV and urinated 250cc, followed by an additional 40mg IV Lasix and urinated 300cc. She then developed hypotension and went into Afib with RVR.
* The patient was given 10mg Diltiazem bolus x 2, followed by a Diltiazem drip at 20mg/hr to control her heart rate. She was also given neosynephrine to maintain her blood pressure.
* At 20:45, the patient entered a paced rhythm at a ventricular rate of 60, and the Diltiazem drip was held. Her blood pressure fell to approximately 52, and she was given a 250cc NS bolus x2 and another 500cc this morning for low blood pressure. She was also started on stress dose steroids.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 102.2°F (39°C)
* Heart rate: 76 (60-148) bpm
* Blood pressure: 109/41 (60-157/57-92) mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 (11-20) inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 89-93% on FiO2 51%
* Pulse oximetry: 89-93%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 14.3 (15.0-8.7) x10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 35.1 (32.6-29.5)%
* Platelet count: 288 (209-212) x10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.5 (1.1-1.1) mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.14 (0.11-0.09) ng/mL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 33 (34-33) mg/dL
* Glucose: 192 (218-262) mg/dL

The patient's medical complications include:

* Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (Afib with RVR)
* Hypotension
* Respiratory failure
* Flash pulmonary edema
* Leukocytosis
* Acute renal failure
* Sarcoidosis
* Diabetes type 2
* Dyslipidemia
* Hypothyroidism
* Depression
* GERD

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue Diltiazem drip and neosynephrine to control her heart rate and blood pressure
* Monitor for signs of respiratory failure and adjust ventilation as needed
* Continue antibiotics for suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Consider tube feeds if the patient fails weaning from mechanical ventilation
* Monitor for signs of acute renal failure and adjust fluid management as needed
* Continue stress dose steroids
* Monitor for signs of leukocytosis and adjust antibiotics as needed
* Consider empiric treatment for Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection
* Monitor for signs of sarcoidosis and adjust treatment as needed
* Continue diabetes management
* Monitor for signs of dyslipidemia and adjust treatment as needed
* Continue thyroid replacement therapy
* Continue depression treatment
* Continue GERD treatment

The patient's disposition is to remain in the ICU for now, with plans to transfer to the coronary care unit (CCU) once her condition stabilizes.

   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient with multiple episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since
   admission, including yesterday evening. She was sent for cath and found
   to have 2 vessel disease, s/p BMS to LAD.  She now is intubated, on
   some sedation, and continues to have volatile blood pressure control
   and episodes of Afib with RVR.
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with continued episodes of Afib with RVR with
   hemodynamic instability.
   - Will d/c the dilt drip at this time and start metoprolol 100mg po
   TID, will also give 5mg IV lopressor bolus at this time
   - Since patient has a DDD pacemaker, will not hold back on nodal agents
   as needed for RVR, as patient will be paced out of bradycardia.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR at goal of [**1-29**] today (INR=2.5), will continue home dose of
   coumadin
   - Will continue to rate control per EP
   - Contact outside cardiologist and pulmonologist for ?amiodarone
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: found to have 2 vessel disease on cardiac cath
   s/p BMS to the mid LAD. ? whether this was a primary coronary event or
   demand [**1-28**] RVR as pt. had acute heart failure yesterday and still has
   not significantly increased her troponin, would have expected large
   bump by now if infarct large enough to cause LV failure. EKG does
   appear to be c/w s/p anterior infarct.   TTE yesterday showed normal
   EF, focal hypokinesis of apical free wall of RV, and severe pulmonary
   systolic hypertension.
   - Integrillin gtt has now stopped
   - Completed ASA desensitization yesterday
   - Switched Plavix 75 mg to daily instead of [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   - Metoprolol to start today per above
   - Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension, dye in cath, and bump in
   creatinine
   .
   # PUMP: EF of >55% per TTE yesterday. Current BNP.  Fluid overload
   possibly secondary afib with RVR; this is likely the etiology behind
   her flash pulmonary edema.  She is likely still fluid overloaded, but
   has been hypotensive with MAPs in the 50
s overnight.
   - Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and currently in Afib
   with RVR
   - Once stable, will consider diuresing again
   - Started on stress dose steroids in order to supplement BP given
   possibility of adrenal insufficiency
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF and complicated by severe pulmonary
   hypertension
   - intubated on AC; can attempt PS again today and ultimately wean from
   vent when HD stable
   - Serial ABG's
   - CXR in AM
   -  Will avoid albuterol [**1-28**] terbutaline allergy
   .
   #Anemia: Continues to trend down. Unable to guaiac stool (no BM). At
   this time thought to be secondary to marrow suppression.
   - Trend HCT
   # Respiratory Acidosis with Metabolic Compensation: Patient h/o COPD on
   home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis. Acid/Base disturbance likely
   secondary to COPD, as patient may be a CO2 retainer.
   - Continue to monitor with ABG's
   - Adjust major acid/base disturbances with ventilation manipulation
   .
   # Fever/Leukocytosis: Patient still febrile to 102.2 with resolution of
   her leukocytosis (WBC 8.7 this am).  Being treated with Vanc/Cefepime
   and now with positive blood cultures of GPC.  Urine cx neg, sputum
   showed oropharyngeal flora.
   - Continue Vanc/cefepime (Day [**2-2**])
   - Will stop flagyl at this time as concern for C Diff low
   - Antibiotics approval received for Vanc/Cefepime
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Patient with bump in creatinine today to 1.5
   (from 1.1 yesterday), likely prerenal etiology as consistently
   hypotensive overnight.  [**Month (only) 51**] also be related to dye given during cath,
   and possible septic shock.
   - Will calculate FeUrea to evaluated for prerenal etiology
   - Monitor creatinine daily
   - Continue to support BP for increased renal perfusion
   - Rate control her Afib to increased forward flow from heart
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Switched to stress dose steroids
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now.

   # Depression:

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and sarcoidosis who was admitted with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has had multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (Afib with RVR) and hypotension since admission. She has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. Her laboratory results show mild anemia, respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation, and acute renal failure. She has been treated with antibiotics for suspected sepsis, and her blood cultures have grown Gram-positive cocci in clusters. She has also been started on stress dose steroids due to the possibility of adrenal insufficiency.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued Afib with RVR: The patient's episodes of Afib with RVR are likely to continue, and it is essential to control her heart rate to prevent further cardiac complications.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level has increased, and it is necessary to monitor her renal function closely to prevent further deterioration.
3. Sepsis: The patient's blood cultures have grown Gram-positive cocci in clusters, and it is essential to continue antibiotic therapy to prevent sepsis.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, and it is necessary to monitor her respiratory function closely to prevent further complications.
5. Fluid Overload: The patient is likely to be fluid overloaded, and it is essential to monitor her fluid status closely to prevent further complications.
6. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is unstable, and it is essential to monitor her blood pressure closely to prevent further complications.
7. Fever/Leukocytosis: The patient's fever and leukocytosis are likely to be related to her sepsis, and it is essential to monitor her temperature and white blood cell count closely to prevent further complications.

Plan:

1. Continue antibiotic therapy for suspected sepsis.
2. Monitor the patient's renal function closely to prevent further deterioration.
3. Continue to control the patient's heart rate to prevent further cardiac complications.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory function closely to prevent further complications.
5. Monitor the patient's fluid status closely to prevent further complications.
6. Monitor the patient's blood pressure closely to prevent further complications.
7. Consider switching to a beta blocker for rate control in Afib with RVR.
8. Continue to provide stress dose steroids to prevent adrenal insufficiency.
9. Monitor the patient's temperature and white blood cell count closely to prevent further complications.

s overnight.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and sarcoidosis, who presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has been intubated and is currently on mechanical ventilation. She has had multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (Afib with RVR) and hypotension since admission. Her condition is complicated by severe pulmonary hypertension, 2-vessel coronary disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac:
	* Continued episodes of Afib with RVR may lead to hemodynamic instability and further complications.
	* Pulmonary hypertension may exacerbate right ventricular failure and worsen cardiac output.
	* Coronary disease may lead to myocardial infarction or further cardiac complications.
2. Respiratory:
	* Prolonged intubation and mechanical ventilation may lead to ventilator-associated lung injury and respiratory failure.
	* COPD may worsen with prolonged intubation and may require more aggressive treatment.
3. Renal:
	* Prerenal azotemia may worsen with continued hypotension and may require more aggressive fluid management.
	* Acute kidney injury may occur due to hypotension, sepsis, or other complications.
4. Infectious:
	* Positive blood cultures for GPC may indicate sepsis or endocarditis, which requires prompt treatment.
	* Urine cultures are negative, but further evaluation is needed to rule out other infections.
5. Metabolic:
	* Hypoglycemia may occur due to insulin therapy or other medications.
	* Hyperglycemia may worsen with continued stress and may require more aggressive treatment.
6. Hematological:
	* Leukocytosis may indicate infection or inflammation, which requires further evaluation and treatment.
	* Thrombocytopenia may occur due to sepsis or other complications.
7. Neurological:
	* Sedation and intubation may lead to neurological complications, such as delirium or seizures.
	* Hypothyroidism may worsen with prolonged intubation and may require more aggressive treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust therapy as needed to control Afib with RVR.
2. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory status, including mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust fluid management and diuretic therapy as needed.
4. Continue to treat the patient's infections, including GPC sepsis and potential C. difficile infection.
5. Monitor the patient's metabolic status, including blood glucose levels, and adjust therapy as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's hematological status, including platelet count, and adjust therapy as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's neurological status, including sedation and delirium, and adjust therapy as needed.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment to manage her complex medical condition and prevent further complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient with multiple episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since
   admission, including yesterday evening. She was sent for cath and found
   to have 2 vessel disease, s/p BMS to LAD.  She now is intubated, on
   some sedation, and continues to have volatile blood pressure control
   and episodes of Afib with RVR.
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with continued episodes of Afib with RVR with
   hemodynamic instability.
   - Dilt gtt restarted this morning at 10mg/hr, will titrate to maintain
   HR < 110;
   - Since patient has a DDD pacemaker, will not hold back on nodal agents
   as needed for RVR, as patient will be paced out of bradycardia.
   - Will restart Neo gtt as necessary to maintain MAP > 60
   - Consider low dose metroprolol later today if BP stabilizes
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR at goal of [**1-29**] today (INR=2.5), will continue home dose of
   coumadin
   - Will continue to rate control per EP
   - Contact outside cardiologist and pulmonologist for ?amiodarone
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: found to have 2 vessel disease on cardiac cath
   s/p BMS to the mid LAD. ? whether this was a primary coronary event or
   demand [**1-28**] RVR as pt. had acute heart failure yesterday and still has
   not significantly increased her troponin, would have expected large
   bump by now if infarct large enough to cause LV failure. EKG does
   appear to be c/w s/p anterior infarct.   TTE yesterday showed normal
   EF, focal hypokinesis of apical free wall of RV, and severe pulmonary
   systolic hypertension.
   - Integrillin gtt has now stopped
   - Completed ASA desensitization yesterday
   - Switched Plavix 75 mg to daily instead of [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   - Start metroprolol low dose later today if BP tolerates
   - Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension, dye in cath, and bump in
   creatinine
   .
   # PUMP: EF of >55% per TTE yesterday. Current BNP.  Fluid overload
   possibly secondary afib with RVR; this is likely the etiology behind
   her flash pulmonary edema.  She is likely still fluid overloaded, but
   has been hypotensive with MAPs in the 50
s overnight.
   - Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and currently in Afib
   with RVR
   - Once stable, will consider diuresing again
   - Started on stress dose steroids in order to supplement BP given
   possibility of adrenal insufficiency
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF and complicated by severe pulmonary
   hypertension
   - intubated on AC; can attempt PS again today and ultimately wean from
   vent when HD stable
   - Serial ABG's
   - CXR in AM
   -  Will avoid albuterol [**1-28**] terbutaline allergy
   # Respiratory Acidosis with Metabolic Compensation: Patient h/o COPD on
   home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis. Acid/Base disturbance likely
   secondary to COPD, as patient may be a CO2 retainer.
   - Continue to monitor with ABG's
   - Adjust major acid/base disturbances with ventilation manipulation
   .
   # Fever/Leukocytosis: Patient still febrile to 102.2 with resolution of
   her leukocytosis (WBC 8.7 this am).  Being treated with Vanc/Cefepime
   and now with positive blood cultures of GPC.  Urine cx neg, sputum
   showed oropharyngeal flora.
   - Continue Vanc/cefepime (Day [**2-2**])
   - Continue Flagyl for possible C Diff infection, as cannot rule that
   out
   - Antibiotics approval received for Vanc/Cefepime
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Patient with bump in creatinine today to 1.5
   (from 1.1 yesterday), likely prerenal etiology as consistently
   hypotensive overnight.  [**Month (only) 51**] also be related to dye given during cath,
   and possible septic shock.
   - Will calculate FeUrea to evaluated for prerenal etiology
   - Monitor creatinine daily
   - Continue to support BP for increased renal perfusion
   - Rate control her Afib to increased forward flow from heart
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Switched to stress dose steroids
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now.
   Fingersticks 231-332, not well-controlled.
   -Start humulog ISS for more predictable control, will add lantus dose
   for basal insulin
   -FSBS qac and qhs
   .
   # Dyslipidemia: Lipid panel drawn yesterday (see above)
   - Holding zetia for now
   - On simvastatin 80 mg daily
   # Hypothyroidism:
   -Continue Synthroid at 25 mcg daily
   # Depression:
   -Continue Paroxetine 10 mg daily
   # GERD:
   -Start H2 blocker (Famotidine) as PPI interacts with Plavix
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: On tube feeds now
   Glycemic Control:  ISS
   Lines:  Multi Lumen - [**2182-7-16**] 07:06 PM left femoral, A-line, 20
   Gauge - [**2182-7-17**] 12:50 AM
   Consider PICC line.

   DVT:  Boots, therapeutic INR
   Stress ulcer:  Famotidine 20 mg daily

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and sarcoidosis, who presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has been intubated and is currently in atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR). The patient has a DDD pacemaker and has undergone cardiac catheterization, which revealed 2-vessel disease. She has been treated with various medications, including diuretics, beta blockers, and anticoagulants.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR): The patient's AFib with RVR is likely to continue, requiring close monitoring and rate control measures.
2. Pulmonary edema: The patient's flash pulmonary edema may lead to ongoing respiratory failure, requiring continued mechanical ventilation and fluid management.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's bump in creatinine suggests possible AKI, which may be related to prerenal etiology, dye exposure during cardiac catheterization, or septic shock.
4. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood cultures and febrile response suggest possible sepsis, which may be related to her underlying medical conditions or hospital-acquired infections.
5. Respiratory acidosis: The patient's respiratory acidosis may persist due to her chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and potential CO2 retention.
6. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may continue due to her underlying medical conditions, medication side effects, or septic shock.
7. Cardiac complications: The patient's 2-vessel disease and AFib with RVR may lead to ongoing cardiac complications, including cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or myocardial infarction.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and rate control measures.
2. Manage the patient's pulmonary edema with continued mechanical ventilation and fluid management.
3. Evaluate and manage the patient's AKI, sepsis, and respiratory acidosis.
4. Consider stress dose steroids to support the patient's blood pressure and adrenal function.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust her insulin regimen as needed.
6. Consider switching to a more aggressive diuretic regimen to manage the patient's fluid overload.
7. Consult with the patient's cardiologist and pulmonologist regarding further management and treatment options.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and sarcoidosis, who presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has been intubated and is currently in atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR) with hemodynamic instability. She has undergone cardiac catheterization and has been found to have 2-vessel disease with a stent placed in the mid-left anterior descending artery. She is being treated with medications to control her heart rate, blood pressure, and fluid overload.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued episodes of AFib with RVR and hemodynamic instability, which may lead to further cardiovascular instability and potential cardiac arrest.
2. Pulmonary hypertension, which may worsen respiratory failure and increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypotension, fluid overload, and potential septic shock, which may lead to a need for dialysis.
4. Sepsis and septic shock due to positive blood cultures of GPC, which may lead to organ dysfunction and potential mortality.
5. Respiratory failure, which may worsen due to continued fluid overload and pulmonary hypertension.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding due to stress ulceration, which may worsen due to continued use of anticoagulation therapy.
7. Worsening of anemia due to continued marrow suppression, which may worsen due to continued use of anticoagulation therapy.
8. Hyperglycemia due to continued use of insulin and glucose infusions, which may worsen due to continued stress response.
9. Hypothyroidism, which may worsen due to continued use of antithyroid medication.
10. Potential for further complications due to continued use of anticoagulation therapy, such as bleeding or thrombosis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular stability and adjust medications as needed to control her heart rate and blood pressure.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust medications as needed to prevent further AKI.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's blood cultures and adjust antibiotics as needed to treat the underlying infection.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust medications as needed to prevent further bleeding.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust medications as needed to prevent further worsening.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's hyperglycemia and adjust medications as needed to prevent further worsening.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's hypothyroidism and adjust medications as needed to prevent further worsening.
9. Consider consulting with a cardiologist to discuss further management of the patient's cardiac condition.
10. Consider consulting with a nephrologist to discuss further management of the patient's renal condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and sarcoidosis, who presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She was intubated and sedated due to respiratory failure.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Cardiovascular: AFib with RVR has been controlled with metoprolol and amiodarone. She has 2-vessel disease and has undergone BMS to the mid-LAD.
* Respiratory: She is intubated and on AC, with a plan to wean her off the ventilator when hemodynamically stable. She has a history of flash pulmonary edema and is at risk for respiratory failure.
* Renal: Her creatinine has decreased from 1.5 to 1.1, and she is at risk for acute renal failure due to hypotension and Afib with RVR.
* Hematological: She has anemia, which is thought to be secondary to marrow suppression. Her HCT is stable at 25%.
* Infectious: She has a positive blood culture for Staphylococcus, coagulase-negative, and is being treated with vancomycin and cefepime. She has a history of fever and leukocytosis.
* Endocrine: She has diabetes type 2 and is being treated with Lantus and Humalog. Her blood sugar levels are not well-controlled, and she requires 22 units of Humalog.
* Other: She has a history of sarcoidosis, hypercalcemia, and dyslipidemia.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to her history of flash pulmonary edema and her current respiratory status.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine has decreased, but she is still at risk for acute renal failure due to hypotension and Afib with RVR.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia is thought to be secondary to marrow suppression, and she may require further transfusions.
4. Infection: The patient has a positive blood culture and is being treated with antibiotics. She is at risk for developing sepsis and multi-organ failure.
5. Cardiovascular: The patient has a history of Afib with RVR and has undergone BMS to the mid-LAD. She is at risk for further cardiac complications, such as heart failure and arrhythmias.
6. Endocrine: The patient's diabetes is not well-controlled, and she requires further management to prevent complications.
7. Sarcoidosis: The patient has a history of sarcoidosis, and she may require further treatment to manage her symptoms.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue metoprolol and amiodarone to control Afib with RVR.
2. Wean the patient off the ventilator when hemodynamically stable.
3. Monitor the patient's creatinine and adjust her fluid management accordingly.
4. Continue antibiotics for her positive blood culture.
5. Monitor the patient's anemia and transfuse as necessary.
6. Continue to manage the patient's diabetes and adjust her medications as necessary.
7. Consider diuresis when the patient is stable.
8. Continue stress dose steroids to manage the patient's possible adrenal insufficiency.
9. Monitor the patient's electrolytes and adjust her medications as necessary.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her oxygen therapy as necessary.

   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient with multiple episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since
   admission. She was sent for cath and found to have 2 vessel disease,
   s/p BMS to LAD.  She now is intubated, sedated. AFib now controlled.
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus for approx. 24 hours. EKG with long QTc.
   - Continue Metoprolol 100mg po TID; once she has 5 grams of amio, will
   cut back metoprolol to [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Continue Amiodarone 400mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR at goal of [**1-29**], today (INR=2.6), since patient will be long term
   in CCU, will stop coumadin and allow drift of INR to 2
 and will need
   to place PICC at that time.
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: 2 vessel disease s/p BMS to the mid LAD.
   - Plavix 75 mg Daily
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   -  ASA 325 mg Daily
   - Metoprolol to start today per above
   - Hold ACE for now, one more day without hypotension and good urine
   output.
   .
   # Fever/Leukocytosis: Patient still febrile to 100.2 with resolution of
   her leukocytosis (WBC 5.1 this am).  Being treated with Vanc/Cefepime
   and now with positive blood cultures of GPC.  Urine cx neg, sputum
   showed oropharyngeal flora.
   - Fu Blood Cultures (7/22,[**7-18**]) and Sputum ([**7-17**]).
   - FU sensitivities from positive blood culture
   - Continue Vanc/cefepime (Day [**3-2**]); Vanc level high and last nights
   vanc dose was held. Will continue to monitor
   - Stopped flagyl at this time as concern for C Diff low
   - Antibiotics approval received for Vanc/Cefepime
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF and complicated by severe pulmonary
   hypertension. Mucus plug removed yesterday.
   - intubated on AC; wean peap and attempt PS again today and ultimately
   wean from vent when HD stable
   - Serial ABG's
   - CXR in AM
   -  Will avoid albuterol [**1-28**] terbutaline allergy
   - Pulmonary following
appreciate recs
   - Lung CT scan w/o contrast per Pulmonary
   .
   # PUMP: EF of >55% per TTE yesterday. Fluid overload possibly secondary
   afib with RVR; this is likely the etiology behind her flash pulmonary
   edema.  . To date patient is positive approx. one liter.
   - Once stable, will consider diuresing again
   - Started on stress dose steroids in order to supplement BP given
   possibility of adrenal insufficiency
   .
   #Anemia: Stable since yesterday (25). Unable to guaiac stool (no BM).
   At this time thought to be secondary to marrow suppression.
   -          Trend HCT daily
   -          Transfuse < 21.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Crt down today from 1.5 to 1.1. Most likely
   secondary to hypotension in setting of afib rvr.  FeUrea 8.16% is
   consistent with pre renal etiology..
   - Monitor creatinine daily
   - Continue to support BP for increased renal perfusion
   - Rate control her Afib to increased forward flow from heart
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Switched to stress dose steroids
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and sarcoidosis who presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has been intubated and sedated due to hypotension and respiratory failure. Her rhythm has been converted to sinus rhythm with the use of metoprolol and amiodarone. She has a positive blood culture for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus and is being treated with vancomycin and cefepime. Her creatinine has decreased from 1.5 to 1.1, and she is being monitored for acute renal failure. She has a history of anemia and is being transfused with packed red blood cells. She is also being treated for hypothyroidism, depression, and GERD.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood culture and ongoing febrile response increase the risk of developing sepsis.
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's decreased creatinine levels and ongoing fluid overload may indicate acute kidney injury.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's ongoing need for mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy increases the risk of developing respiratory failure.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of acute heart failure and ongoing hypotension may lead to cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's history of GERD and ongoing use of antacids and H2 blockers increases the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's ongoing use of anticoagulants and platelet transfusions increases the risk of thrombocytopenia.
7. Adrenal Insufficiency: The patient's history of sarcoidosis and ongoing use of corticosteroids increases the risk of adrenal insufficiency.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results to detect any changes in her condition.
2. Adjust her medications as needed to optimize her cardiac and respiratory status.
3. Consider switching to a different antibiotic regimen if the current treatment is not effective in treating the patient's infection.
4. Monitor the patient's creatinine levels and adjust her fluid management plan accordingly to prevent acute kidney injury.
5. Consider performing a stress test to assess the patient's cardiac function and identify any potential complications.
6. Monitor the patient's platelet count and adjust her anticoagulant therapy as needed to prevent thrombocytopenia.
7. Consider performing a gastrointestinal endoscopy to evaluate the patient's gastrointestinal tract and identify any potential bleeding sites.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR). She was admitted with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema and was found to have 2-vessel disease and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to the mid-left anterior descending (LAD) artery. She has been intubated and sedated due to respiratory failure and has been treated with antibiotics for a suspected nosocomial infection. Her blood cultures grew coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, and she has been treated with vancomycin and cefepime.

The patient has had several episodes of AFib with RVR, which has led to hypotension and flash pulmonary edema. She has been treated with metoprolol and amiodarone to control her rhythm and has been started on warfarin for anticoagulation. She has also been treated with stress-dose steroids due to the possibility of adrenal insufficiency.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of anemia, acute renal failure, and dyslipidemia. Her hemoglobin has decreased from 25.1 to 25.0 g/dL, and her creatinine has increased from 1.5 to 1.1 mg/dL. Her lipid panel shows elevated low-density lipoprotein (LDL) and triglycerides, and she has been treated with simvastatin and fenofibrate.

Potential medical complications:

1. Infection: The patient's blood cultures grew coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, and she has been treated with antibiotics. However, she is still at risk for developing a nosocomial infection.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has had several episodes of AFib with RVR, which can lead to hypotension and flash pulmonary edema. She has been treated with metoprolol and amiodarone to control her rhythm, but she may still be at risk for developing arrhythmias.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient has been intubated and sedated due to respiratory failure, and she is at risk for developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine has increased from 1.5 to 1.1 mg/dL, and she is at risk for developing acute kidney injury (AKI).
5. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin has decreased from 25.1 to 25.0 g/dL, and she may be at risk for developing further anemia.
6. Dyslipidemia: The patient's lipid panel shows elevated LDL and triglycerides, and she may be at risk for developing further lipid abnormalities.
7. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient has been treated with stress-dose steroids due to the possibility of adrenal insufficiency, but she may still be at risk for developing adrenal crisis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's rhythm and adjust her medications as needed to control her AFib with RVR.
2. Continue to treat the patient's infection with antibiotics and monitor for signs of sepsis.
3. Continue to provide respiratory support and monitor for signs of respiratory failure.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust her medications as needed to prevent further kidney injury.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusing blood products as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's lipid levels and adjust her medications as needed to prevent further lipid abnormalities.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's adrenal function and adjust her medications as needed to prevent adrenal crisis.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and atrial fibrillation (AFib) with rapid ventricular response (RVR). She presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema and was intubated. She has multiple comorbidities, including sarcoidosis, which is causing severe pulmonary hypertension. She has also developed acute kidney injury and is receiving supportive care.

Medical Complications:

1. AFib with RVR: The patient's AFib is causing rapid ventricular response, leading to decreased cardiac output and increased risk of cardiac complications.
2. Pulmonary Hypertension: The patient's severe pulmonary hypertension is causing flash pulmonary edema and is a major concern.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, indicating acute kidney injury, which is likely secondary to hypotension and decreased renal perfusion.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, indicating hypernatremia, which may be secondary to fluid overload.
5. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and requires mechanical ventilation due to severe respiratory failure.
6. Infections: The patient has positive blood cultures and is being treated with antibiotics, but the cultures are pending sensitivity results.
7. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin levels are stable, but she is unable to produce red blood cells due to marrow suppression.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's AFib and pulmonary hypertension increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise.
3. Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen, leading to further kidney damage.
4. Infections: The patient's infections may worsen or develop into sepsis.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may worsen, leading to further electrolyte imbalances.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust treatment as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's pulmonary hypertension with diuretics and vasodilators.
3. Continue to support the patient's renal function with fluids and diuretics.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust treatment as needed.
5. Consider starting stress dose steroids to supplement the patient's adrenal function.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust treatment as needed.
7. Consider weaning the patient off sedation and extubating her if her mental status improves.

   Assessment and Plan
   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient with multiple episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since
   admission. She was sent for cath and found to have 2 vessel disease,
   s/p BMS to LAD.  She now is intubated, sedated. AFib overnight with
   inadequate rate control.
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus for approx. 24 hours. EKG with long QTc.  Patient in
   afib with rates in the 100s to 120s starting at midnight; 10 mg IV
   metoprolol and 10 mg of IV dilt did not help decrease the rate. Patient
   with stable BP.
   - Continue Metoprolol 100mg po TID; once she has 5 grams of amio, will
   cut back metoprolol to [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Continue Amiodarone 400mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR at goal of [**1-29**], today (INR=2.6), since patient will be long term
   in CCU, will stop coumadin and allow drift of INR to 2
   - Consider starting Heparin gtt as INR is 1.8 today.
   - Will need to place PICC at that time.
   -Will wean metoprolol to [**Hospital1 7**] at 5 grams of amiodorone is in
   system...Sunday.
   # Fever/Leukocytosis: Patient afebrile overnight with an increase in
   wbc from 5.1 to 13.7.  Being treated with Vanc/Cefepime and with
   positive blood cultures of coag negative staph in
 bottles. Still
   waiting for further culture and sensitivities.  Urine cx neg, sputum
   showed oropharyngeal flora.
   - Fu Blood Cultures (7/22,[**7-18**],) and Sputum ([**7-17**], [**7-19**]).
   - FU sensitivities from positive blood culture
   - Continue Vanc/cefepime (Day [**4-2**]); Vanc level high and last nights
   vanc dose was held. Will continue to monitor
   - Stopped flagyl;
   -  with return of leukocytosis consider restarting flagyl or double
   coverage for pseudomonus
   - Antibiotics approval received for Vanc/Cefepime
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF and complicated by severe pulmonary
   hypertension. Mucus plug removed yesterday.
   - Currently on PS 5/5 with decent ABG and RSBI this AM. If mental
   status improves off sedation, consider extubation today.
   - Serial ABG's
   -  Will avoid albuterol [**1-28**] terbutaline allergy
   - Pulmonary following
appreciate recs
   - Lung CT scan w/o contrast per Pulmonary shows severe sarcoid. Will
   obtain old CT/PFT from outpatient pulmonologist on Monday to help
   better assess disease progression
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: 2 vessel disease s/p BMS to the mid LAD.
   - Plavix 75 mg Daily
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   -  ASA 325 mg Daily
   - Metoprolol to start today per above
   - Hold ACE for now, one more day without hypotension and good urine
   output.
   .
   Hypernatremia: Na 149 today; likely hypervolemic hypernatremia. Free
   Water deficit.
   -          Changed tube feed flushes to free water flushes 50 cc q 4
   hours.
   -          Check Na this PM
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now.  Sliding
   scale with 26 units of lantus not well controlled as fsbs in the
   300s-400s. Insulin gtt started in evening and improving blood sugars.
   Trending down from 415 to 178.
   - continue insulin gtt until blood sugar well controlled. Once at
   optimal level (120-180) will transition to more aggressive sliding
   scale based on amount of insulin needed in past 24 hours.
   .
   # PUMP: EF of >55% per TTE yesterday. Fluid overload possibly secondary
   afib with RVR; this is likely the etiology behind her flash pulmonary
   edema.  . Patient appeared fluid overloaded and s/p 20 mg IV lasix at
   1800 (UOP of 400 cc) and 2200 (UOP 200cc); -220 cc since
   midnight
positive 4.5 liters LOS; patient appears fluid overloaded
   - Will diurese today: 40 mg IV lasix and re-assess from there as
   patient appears fluid overloaded
   - Started on stress dose steroids in order to supplement BP given
   possibility of adrenal insufficiency
   .
   #Anemia: Stable; Hct 26. Unable to guaiac stool (no BM). At this time
   thought to be secondary to marrow suppression.
   -          Trend HCT daily
   -          Transfuse < 21.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Crt stable at 1.1. Most likely secondary to
   hypotension in setting of afib rvr.  FeUrea 8.16% is consistent with
   pre renal etiology..
   - Monitor creatinine daily
   - Continue to support BP for increased renal perfusion
   - Rate control her Afib to increased forward flow from heart
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Switched to stress dose steroids
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   .
   # Dyslipidemia: Lipid panel shows TC 157, TG: 156 HDL 30 LDLc 96; Not
   optimal HDL/LDL level
   - Holding zetia for now
   - Continue simvastatin 80 mg daily
   # Hypothyroidism:
   -Continue Synthroid at 25 mcg daily
   # Depression:
   -Continue Paroxetine 10 mg daily
   # GERD:
   -Start H2 blocker (Famotidine) as PPI interacts with Plavix
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: On tube feeds now at goal.  Held at 0400 for hopes to
   extubate
   Glycemic Control: Regular Insulin gtt
